text: <@U0YBC14Q2|alexf> has joined the channel

Has anyone regularly used RxJava _Single_? I really like the fact that the code is easier documented by using Single, but after using them instead of Observables it seems to me that they are quite limited when you start doing slightly complicated stuff with them.

For example since Observables can have an empty state you can chain together memoryCache, diskCache and network easily in one call like `Observable.concat(memoryCache, diskCache, network).first()`. Singles though will either return something or throw an error so you have to chain them with the `onErrorResumeNext` like `memoryCache.onErrorResumeNext(diskWithSaveInCache).onErrorResumeNext(network)`.

Any thoughts on `Single`'s usefulness?
I guess my biggest problem is that in unit testing I have to start throwing exceptions around to simulate that the memoryCache returned nothing for example
I can’t think of any usecases where I would prefer using a _Single_
unit testing rx will always cause problems
it’s just not “nice” to test it
until we figure out a magical “right way” that is, of course :simple_smile:
do you guys work in companies maintaining products or for customers in different projects every couple of months?
its impossible for me to write a test suite for the projects I work in with the allotted time I have for each
I am at a startup, so it’s just one product
it’s also hard to find time to write tests, but I’ve been trying to do as much TDD as I currently can
but if you can’t find time and are working in an agency, tell your management/sales to start adding test time to hour count
I do it as an option
25% more time if they also want tests
I never got a green light to add that extra time
and I cant blame them. Tests are mostly to help maintaining the code
my projects dont go to iterations after I deliver them
except a couple of bug fixes here and there
yes I suppose it depends
I can’t advocate against tests
I was told that we are a small start up we cant afford to write tests
but I understand the situation
only if you throw away all code each iteration can you not afford to write tests
(which never happens)

>I was told that we are a small start up we cant afford to write tests
Red flag there.
<@U08KMU3UN> we also rush from release to release, but you have to find time to write tests.
I know features change, stuff gets pushed, but trust me, you’ll than yourself later
you can estimate it in. srsly I’d leave the second they told me to not write tests
yea, if you guys own a project, not writing tests is shooting yourself in the foot on the long run
agencies are different because they work with a variety of clients, and depends on how their sales are positioned
takes some time in the beggining but saves a lot on the long run
so the option of not writing tests is simply bad management
the only situation where I think tests are optional is really in situations where you deliver an working app and know you arent going to be working on it anymore
you or anyone else
which is basically my day job
By the way, what kind of tests do you guys usually write ? Unit tests, instrumentation tests ?
Unit
integration tests also dont hurt
while I’m refactoring the app piece by piece, it’s unit tests.
later on I’ll make a full test suite
woof.. instrumentation tests :stuck_out_tongue:
The thing is the business logic code is usually quite small in an app, I end up writing very few unit tests
and I end up writing instrumentation tests which takes ages to set up correctly
Testing?
/gif aint got time for that
the usefulness of tests is counter intuitive
<http://cf.chucklesnetwork.com/items/3/9/0/2/0/original/i-dont-always-test-my-code-but-when-i-do-its-in-production.jpg>
If somebody comments on the lack of tests - blame AndroidChat
/gif gangsta rap made me do it
AndroidChat made me do it

<@U0UEQSNMC>: I am not in an agency by my advice should apply in every product that is going to be changed at least once by some other developer after being written. 

Usually the flow from feature request to implementation goes like this: manager/client requests feature -> I give an estimate -> they say ok start working on it. Now what I simply do is that I never give testing as an option, it is always included in my estimate, it is simply part of the workflow not something extra. If manager/client says "we want it in 2 weeks instead of 3" -> I say how that will affect the quality of the product and how that will affect the future maintainability of it -> Then if they say "do it anyway" -> I make it with less tests and I would leave the company in the near future. When managers/clients are the ones settings deadlines on important products with technologies that they do not understand then they are not worth anyone's time and they are a bunch of circus people.

Again, this advice is only for products that are supposed to be used/maintained more than once in the future.
Bottom line is that I personally always include time to write the tests in my estimates
does make sense yea, but also means less clients
/gif applause
less silly clients and more quality ones. I prefer to work with people that understand that they should leave managing my workflow up to me
Software development is in such a demand that we can choose where to work. For every 1 silly client there are 5 worth working with

just, skype, slack, mail, etc...

finish up by 7

I usually go to the office once a week, just to see the folks and talk face to face, maybe the best option for me is to have that decision on my plate
Even spend less time on lunch, cast screen to a huge plasma and play music
I get really bored, plus I tend to overwork
At the end of the day, I’m a happier worker when I get to do these things
Not having to commute increases my quality of life tremendously
Yep, and with modern tools I don't see lack of communication
Also, less disturbance because if you're in the zone, you can answer 10 mins later instead of being tapped on the shoulder

Does anyone here have like really really good knowledge of GC, lifecycles, and leaks?
I’m…I’m not getting a leak when I expect one
this is the most embarrassing thing ever
lol
If we were really really good with GC, we wouldn't use Java probably.
you mean to say you expect  a leak somewhere and it doesnt happen
I guess we all know how references work and how most garbage collectors work.
and how do you know it is not leaking
because I have spent the past hour looking at the memory monitor not going up. Then I took a memory dump and it’s jus not here
then I jumped to printf logs with statics to count the number of alive references, and it was still one.
are you certain it isn’t a short term leak? Like it does leak but something cleans it up later
those can be difficult to catch and you are likely to miss them without active monitoring like leak canary
I’m trying to leak a whole activity by retaining it on an Observable that’s retained in a DI tree retained in the activity
<@U0B8R3VV4>: Have you tried LeakCanary?

mmm, maybe if you add a refwatcher you can see something

<@U0B8R3VV4>: leak canary works by watching things that are important not to leak <https://github.com/square/leakcanary/blob/9e74a8529ca94287fe0c3b02b7a6b39d51ecd704/leakcanary-android/src/main/java/com/squareup/leakcanary/ActivityRefWatcher.java>

so, if your initial Observable is inside the activity i.e. RxBinding, the whole chain will be stored and GCd alongside the activity
check and mate, Android
but if it’s somewhere else, i.e. repository or static context or application, you leak
You guys using view only at Novoda?
<@U053LEHJN>: we still have UX linked to lifecycle, sadly
so not gtting away from it
Actually what do you guys do for lifecycle. I currently try to keep it in presenter, no android stuff in there. And it’s a compositesub in onAttach (create) and onDetach (detroy)
that was my v1
I’m migrating to v2 because we have requests that outlast the activity i.e. network
we could bypass by storing and refetching on database/memory, which is what I’m trying to achieve
Over a year ago my first attempt was to basically recreate Fragments, but keep things simpler to understand
but if you unsubscribe from the whole chain before that it doesn’t get forwarded from the flatmap
<@U0K1ALDQE>: You have to use takeUntil befre the flatmap, and a different takeUntil or nothing afterwards
and expose the lifecycle events as in RxLifecycle, rather than calling into the presenter
the presenter forwards the view onResume to all the Observables to be created

@Test
    public void testThing() throws Exception {
        Observable.interval(1, TimeUnit.SECONDS).doOnNext(new Action1<Long>() {
            @Override
            public void call(final Long aLong) {

text: <@U0B8R3VV4>: wait what!?
the tricky bit is that you can’t do UI inside the flatmap, so you need an intermediate state store or just suck it up and handle errors by ignoring them
sorry, too much info, it’s better structured on my head
what’s your question
How you handle your observable lifecycle
subscribe onAttach and unsubscribe onDetach doesn’t work for operations that have to outlast rotation, i.e. network call going out and has to be later applied to UI
so I’m moving to something that does by using takeUntil, like in RxLifecycle
ow yeah, true
like your snippet
yep
except that if you do any UI in, say, line 18 before takeUntil(), you’ll leak the view regardless
because that observable retains it
so you have to come up with a solution for that, nominally that all chains do not update UI directly, but a data store
which is what Google wanted all along, except fuck SQLite
